text:

Drunken yobs left children without toys after breaking into a primary school over the Christmas holidays and urinating in a Wendy house. 
The vandals also littered the school's playing area with vodka bottles and smashed up benches, causing hundreds of pounds of damage. 
Disgusted locals have come forward with donations for Borthyn primary school in Ruthin, Denbighshire, North Wales. 
Teachers discovered the damage when they returned to classrooms after the Christmas break. 
Staff found toys soaked in stale urine and empty booze bottles in a play area for children aged two to five 
Headteacher Teleri Jones told the Daily Post : “They broke some benches, were drinking in a Wendy house and urinated there. That is what is really disappointing, because it’s just so disrespectful. The school in Ruthin, Wales, was vandalised (Photo: Google) 
“It’s terrible for the children, but what has been great has been how the whole community has rallied around. We have had so many offers of toys and donations.” Read More 
Councillors condemned the "wanton destruction" and called on locals to help catch the yobs. 
Geraint Woolford, Ruthin's mayor, said: “I am absolutely disgusted by what these people have done. 
“This was an act of wanton destruction without any regard for the children of the school. 
“I would implore local residents to come forward with any information which may identify the perpetrators so that they can be dealt with by the authorities. 
“This type of behaviour cannot and will not be tolerated.” Read More Schoolboy suspended because of incident with chicken nugget 
Town councillor Anne Roberts, who lives near the school, said: “I am appalled by the incident. The school and the parents work so hard to provide for the children in their care. 
“I have emailed the local inspector with my concerns as the rear of the school backs on to my garden. 
“It is a regular meeting place for some young people obviously up to no good, and I have asked for regular patrols. 
“I would also urge Denbighshire council to provide security cameras at the rear of the building to try to combat this anti-social behaviour.” 
Police asked anyone with information to call 101, quoting reference number RC17001590. Like us on Facebook
